snippet: Researchers said Monday that a recent extreme drought in Syria was most likely linked to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising there.
abstract: Study published in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences draws link between global warming, severe drought in Syria from 2006 to 2009 and country's current military conflict; cites studies that show drought was factor in creating social stresses that eventually led to 2011 uprising against Pres Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: Researchers said Monday that a recent extreme drought in Syria was most likely linked to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising there.

headline.main: Researchers Link Syrian Conflict to a Drought Made Worse by Climate Change
